Award.AwardTitle: URM: Howard University Environmental Biology Scholars
Award.AbstractNarration: An award has been made to Howard University to support twenty Environmental Biology Scholars through the NSF Undergraduate Research and Mentoring (URM) program. The program will provide two-year research experiences in environmental biology and ecology to four cohorts of scholars (five students per cohort) starting in spring 2011 and continuing through winter 2015. The Howard University Environmental Biology Scholars Program (HU-EBS) is designed to engage minority undergraduates in designing and implementing research projects that are creative, intellectually challenging and of high scientific merit with a thematic focus on environmental stress and evolutionary adaptation. Our primary goal is to recruit and prepare minority students for careers in environmental biology and plant science. Faculty will engage students in field research and laboratory research related to environmental stress (drought, heavy metals, habitat alteration, climate change) in populations, communities and ecosystems. Scholars will be selected based on their interests, career goals, enthusiasm and ability for productive research as determined by personal interviews, academic performance, and letters of recommendation. Students will conduct research with faculty mentors at Howard during two academic years and summers. Students will prepare research manuscripts for publication and present their research at minority student-centered meetings (Beta Kappa Chi, HBCU-UP, SACNAS) and at national scientific meetings such as the Ecological Society of America and the Botanical Society of America. We will build a supportive community through three types of group meetings each month: Research Forum, Environmental Biology Seminar Series, and the SEEDS Student Leadership Forum. Evaluation of program success will include annual pre- and post assessments to determine how our program develops and sustains participant's knowledge, skills, interest and career choices in biology. The Environmental Biology Scholars program has created a community of learning and peer support that is changing the perspective of HU students and generating a new awareness of career opportunities in environmental biology. More information is available by contacting Mary McKenna mmckenna@howard.edu.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the Environmental Biology Scholars project at Howard University was to identify, recruit, and engage undergraduate students from underrepresented minorities in challenging and stimulating research that will inspire them to seek admission to graduate programs in environmental biology or other areas of biology. As of fall 2016, 17 of the 20 Environmental Biology Scholars completed a BS in Biology; the remaining 3 will graduate with a BS in Biology in spring 2017. More than three fourths (14) of the graduated Environmental Biology Scholars are pursuing careers in science and/or education; the remaining graduates (3) are pursuing medical degrees. Seven Environmental Biology Scholars are currently pursuing graduate degrees in science (including five in PhD programs) and four are applying for admission to PhD programs in Fall 2017. Two of the graduates took positions at the Environmental Protection Agency. Our 20 Environmental Biology Scholars won 22 awards related to their participation in the program including an NSF Graduate Fellowship, Best Research Awards from scientific societies, Research Travel Awards from scientific societies, 3 Phi Beta Kappa inductions and a Luard Fellowship for studying at Oxford University, UK. The research efforts by our 20 Environmental Biology Scholars resulted in 18 presentations at national scientific meetings, 11 presentations at regional scientific meetings and 30 presentations at undergraduate research conferences. PI McKenna won the Ecological Society of America's Award for Commitment to Human Diversity in Ecology in 2015, as well as a HU Faculty Senate Award for Excellence in Mentoring in 2014.

We significantly raised awareness and interest in environmental biology among Howard undergraduates. We significantly raised awareness in the wider scientific community about the talents and interests of Howard undergraduates in environmental biology. The EBS program spawned synergistic activities with partnering institutions UC Davis, UC San Diego, UVA who offered additional research opportunities for HU students. We provided effective, sincere, and sustained mentoring for Environmental Biology Scholars, including faculty research mentors, near-peer mentoring, and group mentoring through the Environmental Biology Research Forum led by Mary McKenna. The Research Forum provided a platform to enhance the critical thinking skills, develop communication skills, and learn about the ethical conduct of research.  During the Research Forum, McKenna provided guidance on selecting and applying to graduate programs in environmental biology. We also facilitated interactions between our students and leading researchers and role models in their fields by inviting talks in our Environmental Biology Seminar Series.  Mary McKenna organized the seminar series to provide the Environmental Biology Scholars with an opportunity to meet leading researchers in the fields of environmental science, ecology, and evolution. We encouraged development of leadership skills through community service and educational outreach activities.  Our Environmental Biology Scholars led a student chapter of the Ecological Society of America (SEEDS Program) at Howard University.  The SEEDS chapter organizes field trips, social activities, community service and educational outreach programs in the Washington DC metropolitan area.
